item.title: polar form
item.description:
a different 2d representation for complex numbers
for complex number with absolute value and argument : which is equivalent to bc of Euler's formula.
This formula can be interpreted as saying that the function is a unit complex number, i.e., it traces out the unit circle in the complex plane as ranges through the real numbers.
NOTE: different phases can represent the same complex number, e.g. and .

item.title: spherical coordinates
item.description:
#blochsphere
generalization of polar coordinates
used to specify a point in space with

radial distance , distance from origin
polar angle between radial line and the polar axis
azimuthal angle of rotation around polar axis
there are a bunch of different names for the angles
NOTE: the polar axis needs to be defined. typically . perpendicular to the so-called reference plane or fundamental plane.

used for the #blochsphere
item.guid: Intro to Quantum Computing/1. Math/trigonometry/spherical coordinates.md

item.title: dual space
item.description:
for a vector space , the (algebraic) dual space is the set of all linear maps
the continuous dual of a Hilbert space is again a Hilbert space which is anti-isomorphic to the original space
NOTE: think of multiplications as linear maps
item.guid: Intro to Quantum Computing/1. Math/vector spaces/dual space.md

item.title: Hilbert space
item.description:
for generalizing linear algebra/calculus from Euclidean to possibly infinite-dimensional vector spaces
formally:

a vector space
with an inner product that induces a distance function for which the space is a complete metric space[1]
this is because we use complex numbers (Euclidean spaces are defined over )




A metric space (set + notion of distance) M is complete if every Cauchy sequence of points in M has a limit also in M. Intuitively: "no points missing". â†©ï¸Ž
item.guid: Intro to Quantum Computing/1. Math/vector spaces/Hilbert space.md

item.title: Definition
item.description:
#qubit #qubitmeasuring #blochsphere
a fundamental quantum mechanical system

A #qubit has a 2D state space with bases and : where


-> normalization condition
and

-> #qubitmeasuring cannot be done directly
Measuring is probabilistic:

and changes the qubit in a process called wave function collapse[1]:

In practice: probabilities are estimated via repeated experiments (trials/shots)


or to emphasize that the qubit continues to exist:


#blochsphere
visualize what a qubit does in 3D Euclidean space -> radial/polar decomposition

angle s.t.


with phase angles .
The corresponding state is: and is thus characterized by the angles and (we're ignoring the first factor).
We can use those angles to visualize the state via spherical coordinates on a unit sphere

as the point with the (cartesian) coordinates


TODO figure out why and are where they are ðŸ“… 2024-10-23 âœ… 2024-10-18

and as

polarizations of a photon
alignment of electrical spin
ground/excited state of an atom
loop current states in Josephson junction



see bra-ket notation


Goes from superposition of several eigenstates to a single eigenstate due to interaction with the external world. See Wikipedia.â†©ï¸Ž
item.guid: Intro to Quantum Computing/2. Basic Concepts/2.1 Quantum bits.md

item.title: 2.2 Single qubit gates
item.description:
#qubit #timeevolution #Pauli #blochsphere #commutator #hadamardgate #phasegate #tgate #phaseshift #axisrotations #Pauli #generalrotation #blochsphere
circuits operating on #qubit s (Wikipedia)
-> book: sections 13.1, 2.1.8, 4.2
Principle of #timeevolution: quantum state at current time point transitions to a new quantum state at a later time .
We use a complex unitary matrix to describe this transition: or in circuit notation:

NOTE:

preserves normalization
circuit is read left to right, but matrix is multiplied from the left
we assume no interactions with the environment/other qubits etc


Pauli vector



like classical NOT gate, flips between and





maps to and to



leaves unchanged, but flips sign of coefficient of -> phase-flip
corresponds to rotation by around -axis in #blochsphere


in the Bloch sphere, we have
applying gives us
so the new Bloch sphere angles are and
